thread.title: European stocks slip as China dents sentiment
thread.title_full: European stocks slip as China dents sentiment

title: European stocks slip as China dents sentiment
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Tue, Oct 20, 2015, 15:16 BST - UK Markets close in 1 hr 14 mins European stocks slip as China dents sentiment By Roland Jackson | AFP – 15 minutes ago View Photo 

Europe's main stock markets slumped Tuesday as investors continued to fret over the broader global impact of China's economic slowdown, dealers said. 
London's benchmark FTSE 100 index was off 0.31 percent in mid-afternoon trades at 6,332.56 points, Frankfurt's DAX 30 index was down 0.32 percent to 10,131.69 points and the Paris CAC 40 shed 0.98 percent to 4,657.96. 
Asia had closed on a rebound with Shanghai ending 1.14 percent higher and Tokyo and Seoul marginally ahead as traders bet on China's leaders unveiling a fresh batch of economic stimulus measures. 
Wall Street was lower just after the opening bell, however, on mixed earnings including a disappointing report from tech giant IBM (NYSE: IBM - news ) which sent shares tumbling after a 14th straight quarter of falling revenues led to a trimmed full-year profit forecast. 
Five minutes into trade, the Dow Jones Industrial Average was at 17,161.86, down 0.40 percent while the broad-based S&P 500 was off 0.26 percent to 2,028.47. The tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index gave up 0.29 percent to 4,891.12. 
Investors were poring over news that China's economy expanded in the third quarter at its slowest rate since early 2009 at the height of the global financial crisis. 
"European equities ... continue to struggle with deciphering the weak Chinese GDP figure yesterday and how much of a warning flag it should be for the rest of the global economy," said Jonathan Sudaria at London Capital Group on Tuesday. 
"Should this be a case of bad news is good news, and expect the central banks to pump up equities in the near future, or does a more sinister path lie ahead -- such as the one put out by Citi recently that suggests China could drag everyone down into a global recession?" 
The US bank had warned late last week that there was a risk of a "contagious slowdown" from China and other emerging markets that "increased the likelihood of a global recession" next year. 
In London, mining stocks fell for a second consecutive day on demand fears because the Asian powerhouse is a leading consumer of many commodities. 
BHP Billiton (NYSE: BBL - news ) sank 2.33 percent to 1,070.5 pence, Rio Tinto (LSE: RIO.L - news ) shed 1.62 percent to 2,400.5 pence and Glencore (Xetra: A1JAGV - news ) lost 1.73 percent to 108.10 pence. 
China also remained in focus after India's Tata Steel (BSE: TATASTEEL.BO - news ) axed about 1,200 jobs at two plants in Britain, blaming the move in part on cheap Chinese imports. 
- Xi seeking closer ties - 
The Tata announcement coincided with the start of a four-day visit to Britain by Chinese President Xi Jinping, who is aiming to build closer business ties. 
French and British media have reported that China has agreed to take a stake in French power giant EDF (Paris: FR0010242511 - news ) 's £25 billion (34-billion-euro) next-generation nuclear power project at Hinkley Point in Britain. 
China is taking a 33.5-percent share in the construction of two reactors at Hinkley Point, southwestern England, in a deal signed by EDF with China General Nuclear Power Corporation and China National Nuclear Corporation, Les Echos newspaper said. 
EDF saw its share price inch ahead 0.15 percent to 17.245 euros in Paris. 
On the downside in France, Credit Agricole (Swiss: ACA.SW - news ) 's share price sank 1.39 percent to 11.00 euros after the bank agreed to pay $800 million to settle charges it flouted US sanctions in Iran and other countries, a person familiar with the matter said overnight. 
The settlement is part of a long-running US investigation of European banks for illicit dollar transactions with nations under US sanctions. 
In Tuesday's foreign exchange deals, the euro rose to $1.1358 from $1.1322 late in New York on Monday before Thursday's interest rate call from the European Central Bank.
